entries.description: `Analytics.enable` refuses to initialize when the UUID is missing or opt-out is permanent, then instantiates `Posthog` with the configured host/api key and `super_properties=self.get_system_info()` so every capture carries OS, Python, and aider version metadata.

entries.name: Telemetry redacts unknown model names before emission
entries.description: `Analytics._redact_model_name` looks up the `model_info_manager` cache and only returns the full name for registered entries; otherwise it truncates everything after the provider prefix (`vendor/REDACTED`) so PostHog/Mixpanel never store user-specified custom identifiers.

entries.name: Analytics.event normalizes payloads across PostHog, Mixpanel, and logfile
entries.description: `Analytics.event` coerces all properties to primitives (numbers stay numeric, everything else becomes strings), mirrors the payload to Mixpanel, PostHog, and the optional JSONL logfile, and gracefully disables providers on transport exceptions.

entries.name: my_models.py tallies token usage per model from analytics.jsonl
entries.description: `collect_model_stats` reads the last N lines of `~/.aider/analytics.jsonl`, normalizes deprecated model names, and aggregates `total_tokens` so maintainers can see which LLMs burn the most usage.

entries.name: homepage.py caches PyPI downloads and badge metrics for the website
entries.description: The script stores pepy/bigquery results under `~/.cache/aider-badges`, retries with BigQuery when configured, and mixes in OpenRouter rankings to render badge tooltips.

entries.name: blame.py computes aider-authored line percentages between release tags
entries.description: `process_all_tags_since` walks semver tags, runs git blame on code and doc files, attributes commits to aider when subjects match, and reports aider's share of modified lines per interval.

entries.name: Analytics.get_data_file_path creates ~/.aider/analytics.json safely
entries.description: `Analytics.get_data_file_path` builds `~/.aider/analytics.json`, ensures the directory exists, and disables telemetry when filesystem errors occur so runs in sandboxed environments fail closed.

entries.name: save_data persists opt-in state and UUID between sessions
entries.description: `Analytics.save_data` serialises `uuid`, `permanently_disable`, and `asked_opt_in` to JSON, catching `OSError` to deactivate analytics, while `tests/basic/test_analytics.py::test_analytics_data_persistence` confirms the UUID survives new instances.

entries.name: Telemetry logfile captures JSONL mirrors of emitted events
entries.description: When `Analytics` is created with `logfile=...`, `event` appends JSON-encoded rows including event name, properties, user_id, and timestamp, a behaviour exercised in `test_analytics_event_logging` to guarantee operators can audit telemetry locally.

entries.name: posthog_error disables the client when transport fails
entries.description: `Analytics.posthog_error` matches PostHogâ€™s consumer callback, prints a marker, and sets `self.ph` to `None` so subsequent events fall back to Mixpanel/logfiles instead of retrying a broken connection.

entries.name: get_or_create_uuid lazily seeds analytics identity
entries.description: `Analytics.get_or_create_uuid` loads existing analytics metadata, generates a new UUID when missing, and writes it back via `save_data`, ensuring opt-in sampling uses a stable identifier across process restarts.

entries.name: is_uuid_in_percentage gates opt-in prompts via hex thresholds
entries.description: `is_uuid_in_percentage` converts percentages to six-digit hex cutoffs and compares UUID prefixes, with tests covering edge cases so opt-in sampling remains deterministic across launches.

entries.name: DotEnvFormatter renders documented .env skeletons for aider
entries.description: `args_formatter.DotEnvFormatter` overrides HelpFormatter hooks to suppress usage text and emits a commented template that lists each env-backed argument with sensible defaults, pointing users at {urls.llms} for API key placement.

entries.name: YamlHelpFormatter enumerates every .aider.conf.yml option
entries.description: `YamlHelpFormatter._format_action` walks through all parser options, determines metavars, default booleans, and list semantics, and generates commented YAML snippets so users can copy a complete config file with placeholders.

entries.name: MarkdownHelpFormatter wraps CLI usage blocks for docs export
entries.description: `MarkdownHelpFormatter` swaps section headings for `##` Markdown headers and encloses the computed usage string in fenced code blocks, making `aider --help-markdown` suitable for publishing unchanged.

entries.name: format_settings scrubs API keys before printing config
entries.description: `format_settings.scrub_sensitive_info` replaces full OpenAI/Anthropic keys with suffix placeholders, ensuring `--show-settings` output cannot leak secrets even when the parser stores them on the args object.

entries.name: format_settings appends normalized CLI/environment summary
entries.description: `format_settings.format_settings` prints parser defaults, inserts consistent headings for env values, and enumerates every argument/value pair so users can copy a reproducible configuration snapshot into bug reports.

entries.name: deprecated.py maps legacy CLI flags to model names with warnings
entries.description: `add_deprecated_model_args` registers shortcuts like `--opus` And `--4o`, A `handle_deprecated_model_args` displays `io.tool_warning` and substitutes `MODEL_ALIASES`so that the old flags continue to work. Test `tests/basic/test_deprecated.py` runs each flag and checks what the alert suggests `--model` with the correct alias.

entries.name: main builds config search order from cwd, repo, and home
entries.description: `main.main` assembles `default_config_files` by checking `.aider.conf.yml` in the current directory, guessed git root, and the user home, then reorders the list for `configargparse` and prints an existence summary under `--verbose` so operators see which file was applied.

entries.name: CLI re-parses arguments after loading dotenv overrides
entries.description: `main.main` calls `parser.parse_known_args` twice, first to discover `--env-file` and then again after `load_dotenv_files` so environment-provided settings override config files exactly like CLI flags.

entries.name: main applies --set-env early to seed process environment
entries.description: Before any network calls, `main.main` iterates `args.set_env`, splits each `NAME=value`, and writes to `os.environ`, rejecting malformed entries with a friendly error so later helpers see the requested provider variables.

entries.name: --api-key maps provider shorthands to PROVIDER_API_KEY
entries.description: `main.main` accepts repeated `--api-key provider=secret`, uppercases the provider name, and sets `{PROVIDER}_API_KEY` so integrations like OpenRouter or Anthropic pick up credentials without editing shell profiles.

entries.name: resolve_aiderignore_path anchors ignore files to the repo root
entries.description: `aider.args.resolve_aiderignore_path` treats absolute paths transparently but prepends the detected git root for relative names, a behaviour locked in by `tests/basic/test_main.py::test_resolve_aiderignore_path` so `.aiderignore` always lives beside the project.

entries.name: default_env_file points --env-file at the repo root .env
entries.description: `aider.args.default_env_file` returns `<git_root>/.env` when a repository is detected so dotenv settings live alongside the project instead of the original working directory.

entries.name: check_config_files_for_yes warns about legacy yes: entries
entries.description: During startup `main.check_config_files_for_yes` scans default config files for the old `yes:` syntax, printing remediation guidance so users migrate to the new `yes-always:` flag semantics.

entries.name: Boolean parsing errors trigger a guidance retry for config files
entries.description: If `configargparse` raises the attribute-error pattern caused by `yes`/`no`, `main.main` reruns `check_config_files_for_yes` and exits early so users see a targeted fix instead of an opaque traceback.

entries.name: --shell-completions streams shtab output for supported shells
entries.description: When `args.shell_completions` is set, `main.main` emits the generated completion script via `shtab.complete` and exits immediately, letting users install tab completion without editing config files manually.

entries.name: write_temp_file builds editor buffers with safe cleanup
entries.description: `editor.write_temp_file` wraps `tempfile.mkstemp`, writes the initial payload to disk, and guarantees descriptor closure even when the write fails, giving external editors a durable buffer without leaking file handles.

entries.name: discover_editor honors VISUAL/EDITOR before platform defaults
entries.description: `editor.discover_editor` picks OS-specific fallbacks (`notepad`, `vim`, `vi`) but first respects an explicit override and the VISUAL/EDITOR environment variables, so scripted and interactive flows open the preferred editor.

entries.name: pipe_editor launches the system editor and captures edits
entries.description: `pipe_editor` writes the seed text, shells out to the discovered editor, reads the edited file once the process exits, and tolerates leftover temporary files when Windows locks prevent cleanup.

entries.name: print_status_message uses Rich styling for editor feedback
entries.description: `editor.print_status_message` writes messages through a global `Console`, defaulting to bold green on success and red on failure unless a custom style is supplied.

entries.name: get_environment_editor prefers VISUAL over EDITOR
entries.description: `get_environment_editor` checks `VISUAL` first, then `EDITOR`, and falls back to a default value, letting GUI preferences override shell editor settings.

entries.name: write_temp_file supports suffix, prefix, and directory overrides
entries.description: `write_temp_file` passes `prefix`, `suffix`, and `dir` through to `tempfile.mkstemp`, writes the seed text, and guarantees the descriptor closes on errors so syntax-aware editors get correctly typed buffers.

entries.name: /model swaps the main model and adjusts default edit format
entries.description: `Commands.cmd_model` builds a new `models.Model` preserving the current editor and weak models, and if the session was using the previous default edit format it switches to the new model's default before raising `SwitchCoder`.

entries.name: /editor-model swaps the secondary editor LLM in place
entries.description: `Commands.cmd_editor_model` clones the current main model, injects the requested editor name, validates it with `sanity_check_models`, and raises `SwitchCoder` so the session uses the new editor immediately.

entries.name: diff_partial_update renders a textual progress bar for partial edits
entries.description: `diffs.diff_partial_update` computes the percentage of original lines preserved, prepends a unicode bar (â–ˆ/â–‘) showing progress, and injects it into the incremental diff so users see how much of the file the model rewrote.

entries.name: diff_partial_update suppresses bogus deletions from incomplete writes
entries.description: When the updated buffer is still streaming, `diff_partial_update` trims the original lines past `find_last_non_deleted` so early diffs ignore trailing deletions that will reappear once the model finishes.

entries.name: find_last_non_deleted scans ndiff output to anchor progress
entries.description: `find_last_non_deleted` iterates the ndiff stream, tracks the last original line retained, and feeds that index back to `diff_partial_update`, ensuring the progress bar and diff window stay aligned.

entries.name: assert_newlines ensures original lines end with newlines
entries.description: `assert_newlines` walks the original content (except the last line) and asserts each ends with '\n', preventing partial diffs from misbehaving when the source file breaks POSIX newline conventions.

entries.name: diff_partial_update selects fence length to avoid backtick clashes
entries.description: Before emitting the fenced diff, `diff_partial_update` searches for existing backtick runs and picks a fence one tick longer, guaranteeing the Markdown wrapper never collides with patch content.

entries.name: Final diff pass omits the progress marker and uses full buffers
entries.description: When `final=True`, `diff_partial_update` sets `last_non_deleted` to the original length, skips appending the progress bar line, and diff's the complete updated buffer so the last render shows the finished patch.

entries.name: diff fences include filename headers when provided
entries.description: If `fname` is passed, `diff_partial_update` prefixes the fenced block with `--- fname original`/`+++ fname updated`, giving LLMs file context even during incremental streaming.

entries.name: create_progress_bar renders a fixed-width Unicode gauge
entries.description: `create_progress_bar` maps the completion percentage to 30 characters of solid and light block glyphs, producing a consistent-width status line for partial diffs regardless of file size.

entries.name: dump pretty-prints debug expressions with minimal typing
entries.description: `dump.dump` inspects the caller frame to recover argument names, serializes JSON structures with indentation, and prints a single-line or multi-line record, making ad-hoc tracing consistent across modules.

entries.name: LiteLLMExceptions enforces parity with litellm error types
entries.description: `LiteLLMExceptions._load` introspects `litellm` for `*Error` classes, raises if a new exception is missing from aider's registry, and maps each class to retry metadata so downstream handlers can decide whether to back off or abort.

entries.name: get_ex_info patches retry advice for provider-specific failures
entries.description: `LiteLLMExceptions.get_ex_info` detects google-auth, boto3, and OpenRouter connection failures inside `APIConnectionError`, converts insufficient credits messages into non-retryable `APIError`s, and falls back to the default retry map otherwise.

entries.name: report.report_uncaught_exceptions installs a GitHub issue reporter hook
entries.description: `report_uncaught_exceptions` swaps in `exception_handler`, which sanitizes tracebacks, deletes the version check sentinel, and calls `report_github_issue` so users can file crash reports with system details prefilled.

entries.name: exception_handler shortens traceback paths to basenames
entries.description: The handler iterates `traceback.format_exception`, replaces absolute file paths with `os.path.basename`, and surfaces the innermost frame's filename/line in the GitHub issue title for faster triage.

entries.name: report_github_issue prepopulates issues with system metadata
entries.description: `report.report_github_issue` prefixes bug reports with aider version, Python build, platform details, virtualenv status, and git version before URL-encoding them into the GitHub new-issue link. With `confirm=True` it prints the payload, asks for consent, and opens the browser so users can file actionable crash reports.

entries.name: report helpers capture venv, OS, and git fallbacks
entries.description: `get_python_info`, `get_os_info`, and `get_git_info` in `report.py` detect virtualenv usage, format OS release/architecture, and gracefully fall back when `git --version` fails. These helpers feed the issue template so maintainers see the reporterâ€™s execution context.

entries.name: Analytics stores opt-in state under ~/.aider and disables on failure
entries.description: `Analytics.get_data_file_path` creates `~/.aider/analytics.json` and turns off telemetry when the directory cannot be created. `load_data` catches JSON errors and also disables analytics, preventing repeated crashes if the cache becomes unreadable.

entries.name: Analytics.save_data redacts IDs and fails closed
entries.description: `Analytics.save_data` writes the UUID and opt-in flags back to disk, but on any `OSError` it disables telemetry rather than surfacing the exception. That ensures aider never crashes due to restricted home directories or full disks.

entries.name: posthog_error callback disables telemetry provider on faults
entries.description: `Analytics.posthog_error` is registered with the PostHog client; any network or API failure clears `self.ph`, silently turning off telemetry. Combined with Mixpanel exception handling, analytics failures never bubble into the user experience.

entries.name: install_help_extra guides users to optional help dependencies
entries.description: `help.install_help_extra` checks for `llama_index` extras, prints a friendly message, and delegates to `utils.check_pip_install_extra` with the correct extra index so `/help` can surface vector-search results.

entries.name: Help builds a local markdown vector index under ~/.aider
entries.description: `help.get_index` loads/persists a `VectorStoreIndex` per aider version in `~/.aider/caches/help.<ver>` and repopulates it from `aider.website` markdown when the cache is absent or corrupted.

entries.name: Help.ask yields doc-tagged context snippets for LLM consumption
entries.description: `Help.ask` queries the retriever for the top 20 nodes, wraps each document in `<doc>` tags with source URLs, and formats the question header so downstream prompts can inject the context directly.

entries.name: Help indexing skips docs excluded by help_pats
entries.description: `help_pats.exclude_website_pats` mirrors `MANIFEST.in` exclusions (assets, `OLD/**`, `_includes`) so `get_package_files` ignores generated or legacy content when building the help corpus.

entries.name: urls.py centralizes documentation links for CLI messaging
entries.description: The module exports canonical URLs for FAQs, troubleshooting pages, term-specific docs, and the GitHub issue template so runtime prompts remain consistent.

entries.name: Help prompts require bare URLs to official docs
entries.description: `HelpPrompts` frames the assistant as an aider expert, tells it to return bare documentation URLs in bullet lists, and injects `{platform}` context about the user's system. The guidance keeps /help answers grounded in shipped docs without hallucinated capabilities.

entries.name: Help initialises HuggingFace embeddings with tokenizer parallelism
entries.description: `Help.__init__` flips `TOKENIZERS_PARALLELISM` on, injects `HuggingFaceEmbedding('BAAI/bge-small-en-v1.5')` into `Settings.embed_model`, and immediately builds the retriever so cached help sessions keep using the same encoder.

entries.name: get_package_files streams markdown assets from the aider.website package
entries.description: `help.get_package_files` walks the `aider.website` resource tree, yielding standalone `.md` files while recursing into subdirectories, letting the help indexer load docs straight from the installed wheel.

entries.name: fname_to_url normalises website paths into aider.chat links
entries.description: `help.fname_to_url` strips the `website/` prefix, rewrites `index.md` to `/`, and converts other markdown files to `.html`, with tests covering POSIX and Windows separators so /help answers point at real docs.

entries.name: /help spins up a temporary help coder and then switches back
entries.description: `Commands.cmd_help` lazily installs extras, creates a `Coder` in the `help` edit format with a 512-token map, appends launch announcements, and raises `SwitchCoder` so the main session resumes with its previous model and map budget.

entries.name: Help.get_index prunes corrupt caches before rebuilding
entries.description: When loading `~/.aider/caches/help.<version>`, `get_index` catches `OSError` and `json.JSONDecodeError`, deletes the directory via `shutil.rmtree`, and rebuilds the vector store so stale cache shards never block interactive help.

entries.name: GitHub issue template collects version and model context
entries.description: `projects/Aider/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/issue.yml` adds a form with two textareas: required block `Issue` and an optional section `Version and model info` with a placeholder (version, model, repo-map tokens). This ensures that bug reports contain key reproducible information.

entries.name: URL smoke test guards documentation links
entries.description: `tests/basic/test_urls.py` iterates through module constants `aider.urls` and performs an HTTP GET, asserting the response code 200. This prevents links in the documentation from breaking: any redirect or 404 will fail immediately at the test stage.

entries.name: ensure_hash_prefix normalizes hex color configuration
entries.description: `io.ensure_hash_prefix` prepends `#` to 3- or 6-digit hex values and leaves named colors untouched, allowing config files to omit the hash without breaking Rich color parsing.

entries.name: restore_multiline temporarily disables multiline mode inside helpers
entries.description: `io.restore_multiline` wraps methods like `offer_url`, capturing the existing multiline flag, turning it off for the duration, and restoring it in `finally` so transient prompts do not leave the REPL in the wrong state.

entries.name: AutoCompleter tokenizes repo files once per session for richer suggestions
entries.description: `io.AutoCompleter.tokenize` lazily reads every tracked file, feeds it through Pygments to capture identifier tokens, and caches them so tab completion can suggest symbols and filenames after three characters.

entries.name: Command completion hands off to command-specific completers when available
entries.description: `AutoCompleter.get_command_completions` resolves ambiguous `/` commands, queries `Commands.get_completions` or `get_raw_completions`, and only falls back to filename words when no command-specific hints exist.

entries.name: InputOutput.write_text retries locked files with exponential backoff
entries.description: `InputOutput.write_text` honours dry runs, retries up to five times on `PermissionError` with doubling delays, and preserves newline settings so aider can safely overwrite files on Windows and network drives.

entries.name: log_llm_history appends timestamped chat transcripts to disk
entries.description: `InputOutput.log_llm_history` creates the parent directory, prefixes each record with role and ISO timestamp, and disables logging after the first filesystem error to avoid noisy retries.

entries.name: offer_url respects prior never prompts and launches the browser on demand
entries.description: `InputOutput.offer_url` tracks URLs declined with "never", presents a yes/no prompt otherwise, and calls `webbrowser.open` only when the user consents, making docs links safe for non-interactive shells.

entries.name: get_input supports brace-delimited multiline snippets with optional tags
entries.description: `InputOutput.get_input` watches for lines starting with `{tag`, keeps reading until it sees the matching `tag}` marker, and preserves embedded newlines so users can paste structured data without toggling modes manually.

entries.name: MarkdownStream maintains a live window while printing stable history above
entries.description: `MarkdownStream.update` throttles refreshes to 20fps, renders markdown into lines, prints newly stable content above the Rich Live panel, and uses the live window for the last few lines so streaming answers remain legible in scrollback.

entries.name: NoInsetMarkdown customizes code blocks and headings for tight layout
entries.description: `NoInsetMarkdown` swaps Rich renderers so fenced code uses `Syntax` without padding and headings stay left-aligned (H1s inside a heavy box), matching aiderâ€™s CLI output expectations.

entries.name: Custom Rich classes remove inset padding for streamed code
entries.description: `mdstream.NoInsetCodeBlock` renders `Syntax` with zero padding and `LeftHeading` left-justifies headings; `NoInsetMarkdown.elements` swaps these into Rich's renderer so streamed markdown stays tight in the terminal.

entries.name: MarkdownStream renders chunks into cached line buffers
entries.description: `MarkdownStream._render_markdown_to_lines` feeds the latest markdown into a forced terminal `Console`, captures the output in `io.StringIO`, and splits it into lines that the live window logic can compare against previous renders.

entries.name: Streaming throttles updates based on render time
entries.description: `MarkdownStream.update` times each Rich render, sets `min_delay` to `min(max(render_time * 10, 1/20), 2)`, and skips redraws until the delay elapses so the output holds roughly 20 FPS without overwhelming the terminal.

entries.name: Final updates clear the live window and stop Rich Live
entries.description: When `final=True`, `MarkdownStream.update` prints remaining stable lines, sends an empty `Text` to the live panel, calls `Live.stop()`, and drops the cached instance so the next stream starts fresh.

entries.name: Rendered slices convert ANSI output back into Rich Text
entries.description: `MarkdownStream.update` joins the stable and trailing slices, wraps them with `Text.from_ansi`, and feeds them to either the console or live panel so syntax colours survive each incremental repaint.

entries.name: Spinner waits 0.5 seconds before appearing to avoid flicker
entries.description: `waiting.Spinner.step` tracks `start_time` and suppresses the animation until 0.5 seconds have passed, hiding the cursor only when the task is genuinely slow so fast completions keep the terminal clean.

entries.name: Spinner falls back to ASCII when unicode writes fail
entries.description: `Spinner._supports_unicode` probes stdout with the shaded block palette and reuses ASCII frames when encoding fails, guaranteeing the moving marker renders even on limited terminals.

entries.name: Spinner trims frames to console width and clears leftovers
entries.description: `Spinner.step` measures `self.console.width - 2`, truncates the animation line, and pads with spaces when the new frame is shorter so successive updates never leave stray characters on screen.

entries.name: Spinner keeps animation phase across contexts
entries.description: The class variable `Spinner.last_frame_idx` captures the last emitted frame and seeds new instances so the bouncing marker resumes mid-cycle instead of snapping back to the start on rapid spinner restarts.

entries.name: Spinner.end restores the cursor and clears the terminal line
entries.description: When stopping, `Spinner.end` writes carriage-return blanks sized to the last frame, flushes stdout, and shows the cursor again so the prompt resumes exactly where the spinner started.

entries.name: get_assistant_mdstream styles streamed markdown responses
entries.description: `InputOutput.get_assistant_mdstream` instantiates `MarkdownStream` with assistant foreground color, code theme, and inline code lexer so streamed outputs reuse the same palette as buffered replies.

entries.name: check_env verifies Playwright install and Chromium availability
entries.description: `scrape.check_env` lazily imports `playwright.sync_api`, launches Chromium once, and reports whether both the Python package and browser binary are present before attempting headless scraping.

entries.name: install_playwright offers pip and browser install commands with confirmation
entries.description: `Scraper.install_playwright` assembles the appropriate `pip install` and `python -m playwright install --with-deps chromium` commands, displays them to the user, and runs them sequentially when the prompt is accepted.

entries.name: Scraper.scrape converts HTML to markdown with pandoc fallback
entries.description: `Scraper.scrape` chooses between Playwright and HTTPX, detects HTML responses, ensures pandoc is available, and funnels the content through `html_to_markdown` so web captures arrive in the chat as readable markdown.

entries.name: Playwright scraper normalizes user agent before fetching pages
entries.description: `Scraper.scrape_with_playwright` launches Chromium, reads `navigator.userAgent`, strips â€œHeadlessâ€, appends the `Aider/<version>` identifier, and sets it via `set_extra_http_headers` so sites receive a realistic browser UA with an explicit aider signature.

entries.name: Scraper can disable Playwright SSL checks when verify_ssl is false
entries.description: `scrape_with_playwright` calls `browser.new_context(ignore_https_errors=not self.verify_ssl)` so users can opt into scraping hosts with bad certificates without touching global Playwright settings.

entries.name: Playwright launch failures flip scraper back to HTTPX
entries.description: If Chromium launch raises (`scrape_with_playwright`â€™s outer `except Exception`), aider logs the error, sets `self.playwright_available = False`, and returns `(None, None)` so the caller falls through to the HTTPX path on subsequent runs.

entries.name: HTTPX fallback reuses Aider UA and follows redirects
entries.description: `Scraper.scrape_with_httpx` builds a `httpx.Client` with the same Mozilla-style UA string (embedding the aider UA), `verify=self.verify_ssl`, and `follow_redirects=True`, returning both response text and the MIME type stub taken from `content-type` headers.

entries.name: try_pandoc lazily installs pandoc for HTMLâ†’markdown conversion
entries.description: `Scraper.try_pandoc` caches `pandoc_available`, checks `pypandoc.get_pandoc_version()`, and if absent downloads pandoc once via `pypandoc.download_pandoc(delete_installer=True)` so markdown conversion works without preinstalling the tool.

entries.name: slimdown_html strips heavyweight markup before pandoc runs
entries.description: `slimdown_html` removes ``, drops any elements whose `href/src` embeds `data:` URIs, and clears attributes other than `href`, reducing noisy blobs before markdown conversion.

entries.name: looks_like_html heuristics gate markdown conversion without MIME
entries.description: `Scraper.looks_like_html` scans the response for tags such as `<!DOCTYPE html>`, `<html>`, `<body>`, `<div>`, or anchor patterns so markdown conversion still runs when servers omit `content-type` headers.

entries.name: try_to_select_default_model picks sensible defaults from available keys
entries.description: `onboarding.try_to_select_default_model` checks OpenRouter tier first, falls back through Anthropic, DeepSeek, OpenAI, Gemini, and Vertex env vars, and returns the associated model alias so new users start with a working configuration.

entries.name: offer_openrouter_oauth guides users through the browser auth flow
entries.description: `onboarding.offer_openrouter_oauth` explains OpenRouter plans, sends analytics events, launches the OAuth helper server, and stores the returned API key so the CLI can proceed without manual key management.

entries.name: OpenRouterModelManager caches model metadata under ~/.aider/caches
entries.description: `openrouter.OpenRouterModelManager` writes `openrouter_models.json`, respects a 24-hour TTL, and falls back to in-memory data when the cache directory is not writable.

entries.name: OpenRouterModelManager propagates verify_ssl to API requests
entries.description: `OpenRouterModelManager.set_verify_ssl` toggles the `requests.get` verification flag used by `_update_cache`, aligning model metadata fetches with the CLI `--no-verify-ssl` setting.

entries.name: OpenRouterModelManager matches route ids with suffix fallback
entries.description: `get_model_info` strips the `openrouter/` prefix, checks both the full id and the suffix before `:` against cached records, and returns context and pricing data in litellm format when available.

entries.name: _cost_per_token normalizes OpenRouter pricing strings
entries.description: The helper converts prompt and completion price strings to floats, treating blank or zero values as free tiers so downstream consumers can rely on numeric costs.

entries.name: _ensure_content refreshes the cached OpenRouter model list
entries.description: `_ensure_content` loads the persisted JSON, respects the 24 hour TTL, and triggers `_update_cache` on demand so metadata stays fresh without redundant downloads.

entries.name: start_openrouter_oauth_flow runs a local callback server
entries.description: The OAuth helper picks an available port, starts a temporary HTTP server that captures the auth code, opens the browser, and shuts down once the callback or timeout is reached, logging analytics events along the way.

entries.name: PKCE helper generates codes and exchanges them for API keys
entries.description: `generate_pkce_codes` builds verifier/challenge pairs and `exchange_code_for_key` posts them to the OpenRouter API with timeouts and error reporting before persisting the returned key under `~/.aider/oauth-keys.env`.

entries.name: OAuth flow persists the OpenRouter key in ~/.aider/oauth-keys.env
entries.description: After exchanging the auth code, `start_openrouter_oauth_flow` appends `OPENROUTER_API_KEY="..."` to `~/.aider/oauth-keys.env` and warns if the write fails so users can export the key manually.

entries.name: OAuth helper waits five minutes and tracks interrupts
entries.description: `start_openrouter_oauth_flow` prints the auth URL, waits up to five minutes for the callback, fires analytics events for user interrupts or failures, and tears down the temporary server cleanly.

entries.name: replace_reasoning_tags turns <reasoning> blocks into readable headers
entries.description: `reasoning_tags.replace_reasoning_tags` swaps reasoning open/close tags for standardized **THINKING/ANSWER** markers with blank lines, making raw responses pleasant in terminals.

entries.name: format_reasoning_content wraps internal thoughts in explicit tags
entries.description: `format_reasoning_content` guards against empty inputs and emits `<tag>â€¦</tag>` wrappers with surrounding blank lines so downstream formatting can reliably strip or restyle the reasoning block.

entries.name: remove_reasoning_content strips tagged thinking blocks
entries.description: `reasoning_tags.remove_reasoning_content` uses `re.sub` to drop `<tag>...</tag>` spans, handles orphan closing tags by splitting on `</tag>`, and returns the original text when no tag is configured.

entries.name: Default reasoning tag encodes a GUID-style suffix
entries.description: `reasoning_tags.REASONING_TAG` concatenates `thinking-content-` with a fixed hash so providers without custom tags still emit unique XML markers distinct from user text.

entries.name: BaseCoder picks a model-specific reasoning tag name
entries.description: `BaseCoder.__init__` stores `self.reasoning_tag_name` from `main_model.reasoning_tag` when provided, otherwise falls back to `REASONING_TAG`, keeping downstream formatting aligned with provider settings.

entries.name: Streaming closes reasoning blocks before normal content
entries.description: `BaseCoder.show_send_output_stream` opens a `<REASONING_TAG>` the first time it sees `delta.reasoning_content`, tracks `got_reasoning_content`, and injects a closing tag the moment standard `delta.content` arrives so transcripts never leave the thinking block dangling.

entries.name: Final responses prepend formatted reasoning blocks
entries.description: `BaseCoder.show_response` wraps any accumulated reasoning with `format_reasoning_content`, concatenates it ahead of the assistant reply, and calls `replace_reasoning_tags` so consoles display **THINKING/ANSWER** headings instead of raw XML.

entries.name: install_upgrade handles docker images and pip self-update prompts
entries.description: `versioncheck.install_upgrade` warns Docker users to pull a new image, otherwise reuses `check_pip_install_extra` with `self_update=True` and exits after printing the rerun instruction.

entries.name: check_version throttles PyPI lookups with a timestamp cache file
entries.description: `versioncheck.check_version` stores the last check time in `~/.aider/caches/versioncheck`, skips network requests for 24â€¯hours, and resets the marker if the request fails so the next run can retry.

entries.name: __init__ guards against broken _version imports degrading version strings
entries.description: The module tries importing `aider._version.__version__`, but if parsing fails or the value predates `safe_version`, it appends suffixes like `+import`, `+less`, or `+parse` to flag the issue.

entries.name: install_from_main_branch prompts for git-based upgrades
entries.description: `install_from_main_branch` delegates to `utils.check_pip_install_extra` with a `git+https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider.git` requirement and `self_update=True`, offering users a one-command dev install.

entries.name: check_version reports current and latest when verbose
entries.description: If `just_check` or `verbose` is true, `check_version` prints both the installed version and PyPI's latest before proceeding with comparison.

entries.name: check_version compares versions with packaging.version
entries.description: `check_version` parses both remote and local strings via `packaging.version.parse`, ensuring pre-releases and metadata are handled correctly when deciding if an update is available.

entries.name: check_version logs errors and returns False on failures
entries.description: `check_version` wraps the PyPI request in try/except, sends the exception message to `io.tool_error`, touches the cache file in the finally block, and returns `False` so the CLI keeps running.

entries.name: just_check flag returns availability without prompting
entries.description: When `just_check=True`, `check_version` skips `install_upgrade`, optionally prints the status, and returns the boolean `is_update_available` for scripts.

entries.name: pyproject exposes `aider` console script via aider.main:main
entries.description: `pyproject.toml` registers `[project.scripts] aider = "aider.main:main"`, so installing the wheel creates the CLI entrypoint without relying on setuptools entry_points files.

entries.name: Optional dependency groups map to files under requirements/
entries.description: The `[tool.setuptools.dynamic.optional-dependencies]` stanza in `pyproject.toml` points `dev`, `help`, `browser`, and `playwright` extras to separate requirement files so pip installs stay aligned with lockstep text files.

entries.name: setuptools_scm writes aider/_version.py during builds
entries.description: `pyproject.toml` configures `setuptools_scm` with `write_to = "aider/_version.py"`, ensuring wheels embed the Git-based version string without a manual bump script.

entries.name: MANIFEST.in trims website assets and docs from releases
entries.description: `MANIFEST.in` applies `global-exclude .DS_Store` and recursively excludes `aider/website` posts, assets, JS, HTML, and YAML so published wheels stay lightweight while still syncing with `help_pats.py` expectations.

entries.name: Dockerfile builds aider and aider-full images with targeted extras
entries.description: The multi-stage `docker/Dockerfile` installs `[help,browser,playwright]` extras plus boto3 for `aider-full`, while the `aider` stage keeps `[playwright]` and adds Google Cloud AI Platform support, both baked into a venv entrypoint.

entries.name: Docker image preps appuser home for playwright and caches
entries.description: The Dockerfile creates `appuser` UID 1000, pre-creates `.aider`, `.cache`, and `pw-browsers` directories, relaxes permissions, sets `HOME=/app`, and marks `/app` as a safe git directory so caches persist on bind mounts.

entries.name: Dynamic dependencies pull from requirements.txt
entries.description: `[tool.setuptools.dynamic]` points the wheel dependency list at `requirements.txt`, ensuring package installs always mirror the same pinned runtime file used by developers.

entries.name: Package discovery is constrained to the aider namespace
entries.description: `[tool.setuptools.packages.find]` limits discovery to the `aider` package so wheels exclude stray modules created during development.

entries.name: Build system requires setuptools>=68 with setuptools_scm
entries.description: The `[build-system]` block declares `setuptools>=68` and `setuptools_scm[toml]>=8` with `build_meta`, guaranteeing version inference and wheel builds share the same backend expectations.

entries.name: requirements.in curates runtime dependencies and pins
entries.description: The base `requirements.in` lists aider's runtime stackâ€”AI clients, CLI helpers, sound libraries, and token graph dependenciesâ€”while explicitly pinning `networkx<3.5`, `scipy<1.16`, and `importlib-metadata<8`. Those caps prevent incompatible transitive upgrades on Python 3.10 installs.

entries.name: Dev requirements bundle linting, analytics, and tooling
entries.description: `requirements-dev.in` pulls in pytest extensions, `pip-tools`, `uv`, plotting libraries, and cogapp so maintainers can regenerate docs, benchmarks, and commit metadata. It centralises optional developer tooling distinct from the CLI runtime footprint.

entries.name: Browser extra isolates Streamlit GUI dependency
entries.description: `requirements-browser.in` keeps the Streamlit dependency outside the core install. Users who opt into the web UI can `pip install aider-chat[browser]` without bloating the default CLI footprint.

entries.name: Playwright extra defers browser automation install
entries.description: The single-entry `requirements-playwright.in` ensures browser automation stays optional. Combined with the `--disable-playwright` CLI flag, this keeps heavy scraping dependencies out of default environments.

entries.name: Tree-sitter requirements split pins by Python version
entries.description: `tree-sitter.in` locks `tree-sitter` to 0.23.2 for Python <3.10 and 0.24 for newer interpreters, working around ABI changes in the parser bindings. The pin is concatenated onto `requirements.txt` during `pip-compile.sh` runs.

entries.name: Benchmark CLI requires docker sandbox and replicates exercises
entries.description: `benchmark.main` aborts with a warning when `AIDER_DOCKER` is missing, asserts that `BENCHMARK_DNAME` exists, and for `--clean` runs validates the target tree before copying each language's `exercises/practice` directory into the dated run folder so benchmarks operate on a pristine clone of the Exercism tasks.

entries.name: find_latest_benchmark_dir picks the freshest run within 24 hours
entries.description: `find_latest_benchmark_dir` scans `tmp.benchmarks`, parses timestamped directory names, filters to the last 24 hours, then selects the run whose hidden `.md` exercise log has the most recent mtime, guaranteeing that `--stats` targets the latest benchmark output.

entries.name: resolve_dirname timestamps runs and reuses unique prior dirs
entries.description: `resolve_dirname` prefixes short names with a `YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM-SS--` stamp, reuses an existing directory when there is a single match and the user allows it, and refuses to continue if multiple prior runs exist without `--new`, preventing collisions in `tmp.benchmarks`.

entries.name: Language filtering only copies requested exercise suites
entries.description: The nested `get_exercise_dirs` helper under `benchmark.main` enumerates language directories, filters by a comma-separated `--languages` list, validates matches, and collects each `exercises/practice/*` folder so benchmarks can target specific ecosystems without touching others.

entries.name: Benchmark runs load bundled LiteLLM metadata before execution
entries.description: `benchmark.main` resolves `aider.resources/model-metadata.json` via `importlib_resources` and feeds it into `models.register_litellm_models`, ensuring local benchmark runs have an up-to-date token/cost catalog even without internet access.

entries.name: run_test short-circuits when prior results JSON is still valid
entries.description: `run_test_real` checks for `.aider.results.json`, parses it with `json.loads`, and immediately returns the cached metrics unless decoding fails, letting interrupted benchmark suites resume without re-invoking the LLM.

entries.name: Solution staging restores pristine files before each attempt
entries.description: `run_test_real` reads `.meta/config.json`, subtracts ignored files (tests, examples, `.meta`, `.docs`, Cargo manifests, etc.) from the solution set, and copies the canonical sources back from the master Exercism tree so each trial starts from the same baseline.

entries.name: Benchmarks extend retry timeouts to 24 hours
entries.description: `benchmark.main` sets `sendchat.RETRY_TIMEOUT`, `base_coder.RETRY_TIMEOUT`, and `models.RETRY_TIMEOUT` to 24Ã—60Ã—60 seconds, preventing transient API failures from aborting long-running benchmark campaigns.

entries.name: Replay mode injects prior chat transcripts into new runs
entries.description: When `--replay DIR` is provided, `run_test_real` loads the previous `.aider.chat.history.md` via `get_replayed_content`, echoes it into the current `InputOutput`, and replays the stored assistant reply before continuing, enabling deterministic reruns.

entries.name: Unit test harness picks frameworks from file extensions
entries.description: `run_unit_tests` maps file suffixes to commands (pytest, cargo test, go test, node scripts, gradle, etc.), copies the configured test files back into the working tree, strips `@Disabled` annotations, and executes the suite with a three-minute timeout.

entries.name: Post-run cleanup purges build artifacts per language
entries.description: `run_test_real` removes `target/debug`, Java `build/`, and `node_modules/` directories between tries, shielding later benchmark attempts from stale compilations.

entries.name: summarize_results prints pass rates, tokens, and projected cost
entries.description: `summarize_results` aggregates each run's JSON, computes pass rates per try, tallies malformed responses, tokens, syntax errors, calculates `$avg_cost/test_case`, and emits a ready-to-rerun `aider --model` command alongside git version info.

entries.name: show_diffs contrasts pass/fail histories across runs
entries.description: `show_diffs` loads each directory's `.aider.results.json`, aligns testcases, and highlights only those whose outcomes changed, printing the history path for manual inspection.

entries.name: rungrid.py batches model/edit-format grids with 10 threads
entries.description: `benchmark/rungrid.py` iterates predefined model/edit-format combinations, skips incompatible pairs, and shells out to `benchmark.py` with `--threads 10 --cont` so large experiment grids can be launched with a single command.

entries.name: swe_bench.py renders pass@1 leaderboards with branded styling
entries.description: `plot_swe_bench` parses text files like `swe-bench.txt`, splits pass rates and instance counts, colors bars differently for Aider results, annotates counts, and exports both `.jpg` and `.svg` dashboards via matplotlib and `imgcat`.

entries.name: problem_stats.py identifies hard sets and parse-error outliers
entries.description: `analyze_exercise_solutions` loads leaderboard runs, tracks parse failures, disqualifies exercises with â‰¥4 JSON errors, prints solve distributions, tallies the â‰¤3-model hard set, and optionally copies those problems into a dedicated benchmark tree.

entries.name: refactor_tools seeds refactor benchmarks with AST invariants
entries.description: `refactor_tools.process` discovers large methods that ignore `self`, copies them into `tmp.benchmarks/refactor-benchmark-spyder`, generates instructions requesting top-level refactors, and writes a unit test harness that enforces the function/class AST child counts via `verify_refactor`.

entries.name: ModelData derives color and legend labels from model names
entries.description: `benchmark.over_time.ModelData.color` buckets model names (Gemini, Qwen, Mistral, GPT-4o, etc.) into consistent palette values and `legend_label` normalizes display strings for the over-time chart.

entries.name: BenchmarkPlotter saves charts to website assets and previews via imgcat
entries.description: `BenchmarkPlotter.save_and_display` writes both PNG and SVG versions to `aider/website/assets/models-over-time.*` and pipes the matplotlib figure to `imgcat` for Terminal previews.

entries.name: load_data filters leaderboard YAML for dated pass_rate_2 entries
entries.description: `BenchmarkPlotter.load_data` reads the YAML leaderboard, strips model names to the first token before `(`, and only instantiates `ModelData` rows that include both `released` dates and `pass_rate_2` metrics.

entries.name: plot_timing groups by model/edit_format and annotates durations
entries.description: `benchmark.plots.plot_timing` pivots the DataFrame by `(model, edit_format)`, colors diff formats green, adds hatching for function-based coders, and labels each bar with the average seconds per exercise.

entries.name: Benchmark prompts add README reminders and test failure guidance
entries.description: `benchmark/prompts.py` defines `instructions_addendum` (warns against renaming functions and adding deps) plus `test_failures` copy that tells the model to treat tests as source of truth during reruns.

entries.name: docker_build.sh produces the aider-benchmark image
entries.description: The benchmark build script wraps `docker build -t aider-benchmark -f benchmark/Dockerfile .`, creating the base image that other benchmark runners assume. It keeps the build command reproducible for local or CI runners.

entries.name: docker.sh launches benchmark sessions with volume mounts
entries.description: `benchmark/docker.sh` runs the benchmark image with 12â€¯GiB RAM, binds the repo and `tmp.benchmarks` directory, forwards the OpenAI key, and sets history variables so aide r records CLI sessions. It standardises the sandbox used during manual benchmark runs.

entries.name: clone-exercism.sh seeds language suites for benchmarking
entries.description: The script clones Exercism tracks for C++, Go, Java, JavaScript, Python, and Rust into `tmp.benchmarks/exercism`, skipping repos that already exist. Bench harnesses use these samples to benchmark aider across real-world exercises.

entries.name: cpp-test.sh builds Exercism C++ suites with CMake
entries.description: `benchmark/cpp-test.sh` configures the C++ exercises with `-DEXERCISM_RUN_ALL_TESTS=1`, generates Unix Makefiles, and runs `make`, ensuring benchmark environments validate all test cases before timing aider's edits.

entries.name: npm-test.sh normalises specs before running npm test
entries.description: The npm helper symlinks pre-installed `node_modules`, rewrites skipped `xtest(` cases to `test(` via `sed`, and invokes `npm run test`. That keeps JavaScript benchmarks deterministic inside the Docker volume.

entries.name: rsync.sh mirrors repo to remote runners with fswatch
entries.description: `benchmark/rsync.sh` derives an exclude list from git, pushes the repo plus `.env` and aide config files to a remote `~/aider` directory, then watches for local filesystem changes via `fswatch` to resync. It's used to keep remote benchmark hosts in sync during iterative runs.

entries.name: plot.sh aggregates historical benchmark runs
entries.description: The plotting helper feeds a fixed list of timestamped benchmark directories into `benchmark.py --stats`, generating comparative charts for multiple model/edit-format combinations. It's a reproducible command lineage for the website's performance graphs.

entries.name: install-docker-ubuntu.sh provisions Docker for benchmarks
entries.description: This script adds Dockerâ€™s apt repo, installs engine and compose plugins, ensures the user is in the `docker` group, and verifies versions. It codifies the setup steps contributors need before running dockerised benchmarks on fresh Ubuntu machines.

entries.name: cleanup_test_output strips timing noise from benchmark logs
entries.description: `benchmark.cleanup_test_output` removes subsequences of the form `in 0.003s` and replaces the absolute path `testdir` to the directory name to stabilize responses for LLM. Unit tests `benchmark/test_benchmark.py` cover both scenarios and make sure that multi-line tracing is reduced to a minimal form.

entries.name: versionbump.py refuses to run unless main is clean and sync'd
entries.description: `check_branch`, `check_working_directory_clean`, `check_main_branch_up_to_date`, and `check_ok_to_push` guard `versionbump.py`, ensuring the user is on `main`, the tree has no uncommitted changes, local and origin histories match, and a dry-run push to origin works before touching versions.

entries.name: versionbump.py edits __version__, commits, tags, and pushes the release
entries.description: After validating the new semantic version, `versionbump.py` rewrites `aider/__init__.py`, stages the file, commits `"version bump to X"`, creates `vX` git tags, and pushes both branch and tag with `--no-verify`, automating the release cut.

entries.name: versionbump.py immediately advances to the next .dev cycle
entries.description: Once the release tag is published, the script computes the next patch version, appends `.dev`, rewrites `aider/__init__.py` again, and commits `"set version to X.dev"` plus a matching tag so development resumes without manual edits.

entries.name: update-history.py stages logs, diffs, and helper history slices for aider
entries.description: `update-history.py` grabs `git log`/`git diff` since the last release tag, isolates the relevant `HISTORY.md` slice into temp files, runs `scripts/blame.py` to obtain the aider contribution line, then launches `aider --model gpt-5` with those artifacts before splicing the edited section back into the canonical history.

entries.name: history_prompts.py enforces terse, non-duplicated release notes
entries.description: The `history_prompt` template bans editing prior entries, insists on bullet summaries of net behavior, demands author attribution for non-Paul commits, and always appends the `aider_line` placeholder under `### main branch`, guiding aide-assisted changelog updates.

entries.name: issues.py collapses uncaught exception duplicates onto the oldest report
entries.description: `group_issues_by_subject` clusters issues whose titles match `Uncaught ... line N`, skips ones reopened via the timeline API, and `comment_and_close_duplicate` posts a canned message pointing to the oldest ticket before closing newer duplicates.

entries.name: issues.py files warning and closure comments for stalled tickets
entries.description: `handle_unlabeled_issues` and the stale comment constants let the script add a two-week warning followed by an auto-close message after three weeks of inactivity, complete with bot attribution links.

entries.name: issues.py labels unanswered questions where paul-gauthier replied
entries.description: `find_unlabeled_with_paul_comments` scans open issues with no labels, fetches their comment threads, and when `auto_yes` or user confirmation is given, patches GitHub to apply the `question` label so follow-up triage can separate user support from bugs.

entries.name: has_been_reopened guards against reclosing actively discussed issues
entries.description: `has_been_reopened` calls the issue timeline API and ensures duplicates and stale candidates are skipped once a human has reopened them, avoiding bot churn on revived discussions.

entries.name: clean_metadata.py diffs aider and LiteLLM model entries before removals
entries.description: The script loads LiteLLM JSON and aider's comment-friendly metadata with `json5`, prints unified diffs for overlapping models, and can surgically excise outdated blocks via `remove_block_surgically`, preventing drift between supplier catalogs.

entries.name: yank-old-versions.py lists PyPI releases still supporting Python 3.8
entries.description: `get_versions_supporting_python38_or_lower` downloads PyPI JSON, interprets `requires_python` specifiers with `packaging.SpecifierSet`, and prints down-level compatible releases so maintainers can yank or document them.

entries.name: tsl_pack_langs.py refreshes tree-sitter tag packs from upstream repos
entries.description: Given `language_definitions.json`, the script probes configured branches, falls back to GitHub's default branch or common names, downloads each `tags.scm`, and caches successes while throttling API requests to keep the language pack current.

entries.name: 30k-image.py generates confetti SVG celebrating GitHub stars
entries.description: `scripts/30k-image.py` embeds the GlassTTY font inline, generates randomized confetti outside text safe zones, and writes a social-share SVG with animated shapes for milestone posts.

entries.name: logo_svg.py subsets the terminal font and embeds it in SVG outputs
entries.description: `scripts/logo_svg.py` uses `fontTools.subset` to keep only needed glyphs, base64-embeds the trimmed font, and writes a glowing aider wordmark, reducing asset size for docs.

entries.name: recording_audio.py turns markdown commentary into compressed TTS assets
entries.description: `scripts/recording_audio.py` parses timestamped markers from docs, calls OpenAI TTS, optionally compresses via FFmpeg, stores per-timestamp MP3 files, and maintains `metadata.json` so assets stay synced with narration.

entries.name: redact-cast.py removes sensitive frames from asciicast recordings
entries.description: `scripts/redact-cast.py` replays cast events through `pyte.Screen`, detects frames containing â€œAtuinâ€ or `[    GLOBAL    ]`, and drops them while preserving all other JSON events in the terminal capture.

entries.name: jekyll_run.sh hot-reloads docs via Docker
entries.description: `scripts/jekyll_run.sh` runs the `my-jekyll-site` image with the site directory mounted, exposes port 4000, and forwards extra flags like `--livereload`. It keeps build artifacts in the container while persisting history to the repo for faster local docs previews.

entries.name: update-docs.sh refreshes cog snippets and analytics sample
entries.description: The docs update helper optionally copies the last 1â€¯000 analytics events into `sample-analytics.jsonl`, runs `cog` regenerations across README and the docs tree, and supports a `--check` dry run. It standardises doc rebuilds before publishing the website.

entries.name: pip-compile.sh drives uv to unify constraint sets
entries.description: `scripts/pip-compile.sh` first generates `common-constraints.txt` with `uv pip compile`, then compiles base requirements and each extras file against that lock. It rebuilds `requirements.txt` while reinserting the `tree-sitter` pins, keeping all dependency sets mutually compatible.

entries.name: tmux_record.sh enforces one-window recordings
entries.description: The recording helper aborts unless exactly one tmux window is open, reads its dimensions, and launches `asciinema rec` against a read-only tmux attach. That guarantees reproducible terminal captures for demos and regression videos.

entries.name: dl_icons.py syncs Material Design assets for the site
entries.description: `scripts/dl_icons.py` downloads the SVGs referenced in the README from jsDelivr, ensuring the icons live under `aider/website/assets/icons`. Running the script keeps marketing assets bundled with the site without manual curation.

entries.name: ContextCoder forces repo_map refresh for file discovery
entries.description: `ContextCoder.__init__` flips `repo_map.refresh` to "always", scales `max_map_tokens` by `map_mul_no_files`, and neutralizes the multiplier so the context-only pass recomputes repositories even when no files are in chat.

entries.name: ContextCoder reissues prompts until mentioned files match chat selection
entries.description: `reply_completed` compares `get_inchat_relative_files()` to `get_file_mentions(..., ignore_current=True)`, clears `abs_fnames`, and sets `reflected_message` when the assistant names new files, giving it another chance before switching coders.

entries.name: UnifiedDiffCoder deduplicates hunks and emits targeted error guidance
entries.description: `apply_edits` normalizes hunks, filters duplicates via a `seen` set, and when a replacement fails it raises a ValueError with `UnifiedDiffNoMatch` or `UnifiedDiffNotUnique` templates that embed the offending snippet and advice.

entries.name: UnifiedDiffCoder.do_replace supports new files and append-only hunks
entries.description: `do_replace` treats absent paths with blank `before_text` as new files (touching them) and appends diffs lacking deletions to the original content, covering pure additions alongside normal patch applications.

entries.name: RelativeIndenter encodes indentation deltas with a unique marker
entries.description: `RelativeIndenter` picks a Unicode character absent from the texts, rewrites each line as a pair of indent delta and content, and later reverses the process, letting search/replace logic survive uniform re-indentation.

entries.name: replace_most_similar_chunk tolerates whitespace drift and ellipses
entries.description: `replace_most_similar_chunk` tries exact and whitespace-tolerant matches, strips spurious blank lines, then invokes `try_dotdotdots` to expand `...` placeholders, maximizing the chance of landing a GPT-authored edit block.

entries.name: EditBlockCoder reroutes SEARCH/REPLACE blocks across chat files
entries.description: `EditBlockCoder.apply_edits` runs through `self.abs_fnames`, tries to bind SEARCH/REPLACE blocks and prints hints `find_similar_lines`, if no match is found. `tests/basic/test_editblock.py` check file name extraction, handling of unclosed blocks and erroneous scripts, keeping the engine from regressions.

entries.name: WholeFileCoder infers target files from fences, context, or chat state
entries.description: `WholeFileCoder.get_edits` trusts headings preceding triple backticks, falls back to filenames spotted in the prose (`saw_fname`), and finally to the lone in-chat file, ensuring the assistant's diff blocks land on the right path.

entries.name: SingleWholeFileFunctionCoder exposes a write_file tool call with planning output
entries.description: The coder registers an OpenAI-style tool named `write_file` that demands a step-by-step `explanation` plus the full `content`, parses partial arguments during streaming, and reflects live diffs for the single targeted file.

entries.name: PatchCoder parses apply_patch style hunks with fuzz-aware context matching
entries.description: `PatchCoder`'s helpers `_norm`, `find_context`, and `peek_next_section` build `PatchAction` objects that track fuzz levels, EOF markers, and chunk offsets, enabling safer apply_patch ingestion within chat.

entries.name: __all__ exports coders so CLI choices stay in sync
entries.description: `aider.coders.__init__` imports each coder class and exposes them via `__all__`, which `args.get_parser` uses to build `--edit-format`/`--chat-mode` options without manual bookkeeping.

entries.name: EditBlockFencedCoder maps diff-fenced format to EditBlock prompts
entries.description: `EditBlockFencedCoder` simply sets `edit_format = "diff-fenced"` and swaps in `EditBlockFencedPrompts`, enabling quadruple-fence syntax without duplicating the base edit logic.

entries.name: EditorEditBlockCoder reuses search/replace engine for IDE integrations
entries.description: `EditorEditBlockCoder` inherits `EditBlockCoder`, sets `edit_format="editor-diff"`, and pairs it with `EditorEditBlockPrompts` so GUI clients get the same apply logic minus shell guidance.

entries.name: EditorDiffFencedCoder enables fenced diffs in editor mode
entries.description: `EditorDiffFencedCoder` subclasses the fenced editblock variant, exposing `edit_format="editor-diff-fenced"` with the editor-specific prompts so IDE clients can request quadruple-fenced replace blocks.

entries.name: EditorWholeFileCoder wraps WholeFile strategy for GUI clients
entries.description: `EditorWholeFileCoder` inherits `WholeFileCoder`, switches `edit_format` to `editor-whole`, and swaps in `EditorWholeFilePrompts` to focus on full file listings without CLI-specific hints.

entries.name: UnifiedDiffSimpleCoder uses lighter prompts for strict diff tools
entries.description: `udiff_simple.UnifiedDiffSimpleCoder` keeps the base unified diff application logic but swaps in `UnifiedDiffSimplePrompts`, which omit advanced guidance so smaller models stick to core diff rules.

entries.name: EditBlockFunctionCoder is disabled until apply_edits is refactored
entries.description: `editblock_func_coder.EditBlockFunctionCoder.__init__` immediately raises `RuntimeError("Deprecated, needs to be refactored to support get_edits/apply_edits")`, preventing the legacy function-call path from being selected.

entries.name: WholeFileFunctionCoder blocks deprecated function-call updates
entries.description: `wholefile_func_coder.WholeFileFunctionCoder.__init__` raises the same deprecation runtime error, even though helper methods like `live_diffs` still exist for future refactoring, so aide never exposes the unfinished mode.

entries.name: ChatChunks controls cacheable message slices for litellm
entries.description: `chat_chunks.ChatChunks.add_cache_control_headers` marks examples or system prompts as `cache_control={'type': 'ephemeral'}` and exposes `cacheable_messages()` so coders can reuse stable context chunks across calls.

entries.name: HelpCoder surfaces docs without ever mutating files
entries.description: `HelpCoder` binds to `HelpPrompts`, reports `edit_format="help"`, and overrides `get_edits`/`apply_edits` to no-ops so `/help` sessions act as documentation lookup only.

entries.name: WholeFileFunctionPrompts enforces write_file tool responses
entries.description: `coders/wholefile_func_prompts.py` defines `WholeFileFunctionPrompts` so tool-using models always respond via the `write_file` function, with reminder strings that block raw code emission or repo dumps.

entries.name: Linux PyPI check compares installs against latest tag
entries.description: `check_pypi_version.yml` installs `aider-chat` on Ubuntu across Python 3.10â€“3.12, parses `aider --version`, and compares it to the newest `vX.Y.Z` tag fetched from git. The job fails if PyPI lags behind releases, catching yanked dependency regressions early.

entries.name: Docker build test builds dev images for PRs and pushes
entries.description: The Docker Build Test workflow provisions QEMU and Buildx, then builds both the `aider` and `aider-full` targets for amd64/arm64. Pull requests run the builds without pushing, while main-branch pushes publish `:dev` tags to Docker Hub so nightly images stay fresh.

entries.name: Docker release mirrors version tags to latest
entries.description: On release tags, `docker-release.yml` rebuilds both Docker targets for amd64/arm64 and pushes versioned and `latest` tags. That guarantees the Docker Hub images match the PyPI release cadence and ship the full `aider-full` variant in lockstep.

entries.name: Scheduled issues workflow triages with scripts/issues.py
entries.description: `issues.yml` runs every 12 hours to execute `scripts/issues.py --yes` with a `GITHUB_TOKEN`, after installing `requests`, `python-dotenv`, and `tqdm`. It keeps community issue hygiene automated without needing a human to invoke the helper script.

entries.name: Pages workflow builds Jekyll and runs linkchecker
entries.description: The Pages pipeline checks out the repo, builds the docs site via Ruby 3.3 with cached gems, uploads the `_site` artifact, then deploys with `actions/deploy-pages@v4`. After publishing it installs `linkchecker` and crawls https://aider.chat, guarding against broken links in production docs.

entries.name: pre-commit workflow caches hooks and emits Checkstyle logs
entries.description: `pre-commit.yml` restores the hook cache, runs all hooks with colorised output, and on failure pipes the log through `logToCheckStyle` so annotations show up in PRs. It always uploads the raw and converted logs as short-lived artifacts for debugging.

entries.name: PyPI release job builds wheels with pinned metadata tooling
entries.description: `release.yml` installs `build`, `setuptools`, `wheel`, and a pinned `importlib-metadata==7.2.1` before uploading to PyPI with Twine tokens. That reproduces the packaging environment that local maintainers expect when cutting a tagged release.

entries.name: Ubuntu matrix installs libportaudio before pytest
entries.description: `ubuntu-tests.yml` fans out across Python 3.10â€“3.12, installs `libportaudio2` to exercise Whisper dependencies, then runs `pytest` with `AIDER_ANALYTICS=false`. It keeps Linux CLI behaviour validated after every push.

entries.name: Windows matrix mirrors pytest coverage without system deps
entries.description: The Windows test workflow recreates the Linux matrix across Python 3.10â€“3.12, installs the project via pip, and runs `pytest` under PowerShell. It intentionally skips extra packages, ensuring the CLI remains functional on vanilla Windows environments.

entries.name: Windows PyPI check uses PowerShell regex for version drift
entries.description: `windows_check_pypi_version.yml` replicates the Linux install check under PowerShell, using .NET regex to extract `aider --version` output. It offsets the cron schedule by an hour so Windows package regressions are caught independently.

entries.name: GPT-4-0125 laziness benchmark
entries.description: Summarizes aider's lazy-coding benchmark for OpenAI's gpt-4-0125-preview release, noting it regresses on unified-diff edits versus the 1106 model while modestly improving legacy search/replace workflows.

entries.name: GPT-4/3.5 November 1106 benchmark
entries.description: Details how aider's Exercism benchmark measures the November 1106 GPT-4 and GPT-3.5 models, highlighting faster runs, higher first-try success, and the need for reliable edit formatting.

entries.name: GPT November speed comparison
entries.description: Breaks down latency measurements from the aider benchmark and shows gpt-3.5-turbo-1106 gaining 6â€“11Ã— speedups and gpt-4-1106-preview doubling throughput over prior releases.

entries.name: Aider code editing benchmarks
entries.description: Explains aider's Exercism-based benchmark suite and compares whole-file, diff, and function-call edit formats, concluding that simple markdown blocks yield the most reliable edits.

entries.name: Configuration guide
entries.description: Describes every aider option and how to set it via CLI flags, `.aider.conf.yml`, environment variables, or `.env` files, including API key discovery and configuration include files.

entries.name: Legacy ctags repo map article
entries.description: Outlines the original universal-ctags-powered repository map that fed context to GPT, noting it has since been replaced by tree-sitter based mapping but still documents the design goals.

entries.name: Frequently asked questions
entries.description: Collects answers on managing chat context, large repos, multi-repo workflows, repo maps, git history sharing, and running aider from source with recommended command patterns.

entries.name: Git integration overview
entries.description: Explains how aider bootstraps git repos, auto-commits edits with Conventional commits, handles dirty work trees, and exposes `/diff`, `/undo`, `/commit`, and configurable attribution flags.

entries.name: Documentation table of contents
entries.description: Liquid template that renders the hierarchical aider docs navigation, sourcing top-level pages and their children for the static site table of contents.

entries.name: Installation guide
entries.description: Covers aider-install one-liners, uv and pipx workflows, fallback pip installs, and platform-specific curl/powershell bootstraps including optional follow-up steps.

entries.name: Language support matrix
entries.description: Lists tree-sitter repo-map and linter coverage per language, explains how to upstream new grammars, and links to tooling needed to extend aider's language support.

entries.name: LLM connectivity guide
entries.description: Summarizes supported OpenAI, Anthropic, DeepSeek, and other providers, covering API key configuration, model aliases, rate-limit considerations, and fallbacks.

entries.name: More info index
entries.description: Parent landing page that links to deeper reference topics such as git usage, language support, and conventions for extending aider.

entries.name: Tree-sitter repo map explainer
entries.description: Describes how aider builds tree-sitter based repository maps, pruning summaries per file, caching results, and letting the LLM ask for additional files.

entries.name: Automation & scripting
entries.description: Documents `/run`, shell integration, custom commands, Python hooks, and environment setup for scripting aider in CI or local automations.

entries.name: Troubleshooting playbook
entries.description: Provides structured guidance for resolving install, API, git, and repo-map issues, including log collection, downgrade advice, and how to get live support.

entries.name: Unified diff prompting article
entries.description: Explains the â€œlazy codingâ€ effect, shows how unified diffs reduce it, and quantifies performance gains versus whole-file or search/replace edit formats.

entries.name: Usage basics
entries.description: Walks through day-one usage: starting chats, adding files, using repo map context, running tests with `/run`, and managing commits during sessions.

entries.name: Individual CLA Aider
entries.description: The document describes the terms of the CLA: Aider AI's perpetual rights to copyright and patent licenses, requirements to disclose third licenses and obligations to notify about a change of status, which is important for contributors.

entries.name: Aider Privacy Policy
entries.description: The page records what data is collected when using the site and tool, highlighting anonymized UUIDs for analytics, opt-out mechanisms, and disclosure procedures for legal requests.

entries.name: Anonymous analytics option
entries.description: The section explains the optional event collection: what metrics are written, how UUID4 works, users, commands `--analytics-disable`, `--analytics-log` and the ability to send events to your PostHog project.

entries.name: Summary of edit formats
entries.description: The article lists the whole/diff/diff-fenced/udiff and editor-* formats, provides syntax examples, and explains when to use each mode, including an architectural scenario.

entries.name: Infinite output with prefill
entries.description: The page explains how aider reruns a request with a partial response prefill, lists the models with `supports_assistant_prefill` and describes the limitations of token limits.

entries.name: Aider.chat home page
entries.description: `index.html` defines a landing page with features section, video preview, GitHub/installs/tokens metrics and links to documentation, Discord and GitHub using custom fonts and Prism.

entries.name: Include with code share graphs
entries.description: `blame.md` connects Chart.js and builds bar charts of the percentage of new rows and absolute values from `_data/blame.yml`, visualizing aider's contribution by release on the HISTORY page.

entries.name: Modifying a 2048 clone
entries.description: Transcript where aider inspects a cloned JavaScript 2048 repo, pulls in `game_manager.js` on demand, and implements a 10% 10Ã— scoring bonus with git commits.

entries.name: Example transcripts index
entries.description: Landing page summarizing representative aider chats, highlighting auto-applied edits, commit logging, and how files enter or leave the session.

entries.name: Black-box test via repo map
entries.description: Shows GPT using the ctags repo map to assemble dependencies, write a `cmd_add` test without source access, then iterate with `/run pytest` output to fix parameter types.

entries.name: Editing an asciinema recording
entries.description: Demonstrates cleaning escape sequences inside an `.cast` file, with aider applying precise diff blocks and committing the streamlined prompt output.

entries.name: Census data exploration
entries.description: LLM-guided session that fetches ACS data, scripts `getdata.py`, injects an API key, and iterates on hypotheses and visualizations for census analytics.

entries.name: Styling chat transcripts
entries.description: The chat tweaks CSS and inline styles to add rounded borders and adjust colors, illustrating how aider coordinates multi-file HTML/CSS edits and commits.

entries.name: Prompt Toolkit input refactor
entries.description: Multi-file prompt_toolkit migration that spans tests and helper modules, interrupts bad replies, pastes docs, and uses `/run` results to converge on passing tests.

entries.name: Completing a CSS animation exercise
entries.description: Walkthrough that reads exercise instructions, adds required files, and authorâ€™s keyframe-based dropdown animation for The Odin Project sample.

entries.name: Building a Flask starter app
entries.description: Stepwise creation of a Flask app that adds arithmetic and Fibonacci endpoints, including refactors and deletions driven through the aider prompt.

entries.name: Respecting NO_COLOR
entries.description: Implements NO_COLOR handling in `io.py`, rewires console colors, and adds regression tests, while illustrating aiderâ€™s prompts for new files and commits.

entries.name: Semantic console refactor
entries.description: Replaces `console.print` calls with `io.tool_error` across `aider/coder.py`, handling differing arguments and demonstrating structured diff edits.

entries.name: Auto-updating README flags
entries.description: Uses aider to sync README CLI flag documentation with `main()` arguments, applying markdown edits and commits after reviewing generated diffs.

entries.name: Transcript of edits hello
entries.description: The chat example shows a simple diff request 'change hello to goodbye' with the result of git commit, demonstrating the response format and commit hook aider.

entries.name: Building Pong with pygame
entries.description: Dialog shows multi-step generation `pong_game.py`, adding Paddle/Ball classes, further requests for improvement and auto-commits of aider to demonstrate a complex task.

entries.name: Repo maps with universal ctags
entries.description: Introduces the original ctags-driven repository map that shipped concise symbol context to GPT, with install instructions and rationale for the approach.

entries.name: Tree-sitter repo map launch
entries.description: Announces the switch to tree-sitter generated maps, explaining the graph-ranking heuristic that keeps the most relevant files within the token budget.

entries.name: November GPT benchmark recap
entries.description: Benchmarks the GPT-4/3.5 1106 models, showing faster runtimes, higher single-try accuracy, and continued reliance on aideâ€™s diff-format prompting.

entries.name: Unified diffs reduce laziness
entries.description: Quantifies how unified diff prompts cut GPT-4 Turboâ€™s â€œlazy codingâ€ behaviour roughly threefold compared to whole-file or search/replace edits.

entries.name: GPT-4-0125 benchmark results
entries.description: Shows the January GPT-4 Turbo preview regressing on unified-diff tasks while only modestly improving legacy search/replace editing.

entries.name: Claude 3 Opus tops benchmark
entries.description: Reports Claude 3 Opus scoring 68% on the Exercism suite, edging GPT-4 Turbo while noting cost, speed, and diff-format limitations for Sonnet.

entries.name: GPT-4 Turbo with Vision regressions
entries.description: Details how GPT-4 Turbo with Vision underperformed previous GPT-4 models and exhibited increased laziness on aiderâ€™s coding benchmarks.

entries.name: Experimental browser UI
entries.description: Introduces the `--browser` flag that serves a local web UI, still editing the userâ€™s git repo and committing changes through aider.

entries.name: Plotting leaderboards with aider
