entries.description: Walks through using GPT-4o to script matplotlib visuals from leaderboard YAML, iterating on runtime errors and styling via aider.

entries.name: Tree-sitter linting pipeline
entries.description: Explains aiderâ€™s post-edit lint/fix loop, tree-sitter contextual error formatting, and `/lint` CLI support for on-demand cleanup.

entries.name: SWE Bench Lite SOTA run
entries.description: Breaks down how aider achieved 26.3% pass@1 on SWE Bench Lite using alternating GPT-4o/Opus runs, lint/test gating, and minimal agentic behaviour.

entries.name: Main SWE Bench SOTA
entries.description: Details aiderâ€™s state-of-the-art result on the full SWE Bench, including harness setup, retry strategy, and practical replication tips.

entries.name: Scaling Claude Sonnet output
entries.description: Describes workaround for Sonnetâ€™s 4k output cap, promoting multi-response stitching and concise diff prompts that lifted refactoring scores to 64%.

entries.name: July 2024 model roundup
entries.description: Summarizes leaderboard standings for DeepSeek Coder V2, Llama 3.1 variants, and Mistral Large, with commands for invoking each model via aider.

entries.name: Avoid JSON-wrapped code edits
entries.description: Highlights experiments showing tool-call JSON wrappers degrade code quality, reinforcing the preference for simple diff-based responses.

entries.name: o1-preview benchmark analysis
entries.description: Shares early o1-preview/o1-mini results, noting 79.7% pass@2 with whole edits, 75% with diffs, and the need for better format adherence.

entries.name: Architect/editor dual-model flow
entries.description: Explains the architect/editor split (o1-preview + DeepSeek/o1-mini) that reached 85% on aider benchmarks and boosted many other model pairings.

entries.name: Quantization and serving pitfalls
entries.description: Compares Qwen 2.5 Coder deployments across providers, showing how quantization, context windows, and token limits alter benchmark outcomes.

entries.name: Using uv for painless installs
entries.description: Covers aider-install and curl one-liners that leverage uv to bundle dependencies, enforce Python 3.12, and avoid user-managed virtualenvs.

entries.name: R1 + Sonnet polyglot SOTA
entries.description: Documents the architect/editor pairing where DeepSeek R1 plus Sonnet hit 64% on the polyglot benchmark at 14Ã— lower cost than o1, with usage commands.

entries.name: Pass rate chart by format
entries.description: `code-in-json-benchmark.js` builds a comparative bar chart of the success of models based on data `code-in-json` and automatically adjusts aspect ratio, highlighting JSON/Markdown formats.

entries.name: Syntax error graph
entries.description: `code-in-json-syntax.js` visualizes the number of syntax/indentation errors by model and format using the same YAML data and labels the values on top of the columns.

entries.name: Filterable graph of quant models
entries.description: `quant-chart.js` sorts data `_data/quant` by pass_rate_2, builds a bar chart and connects a search by substring of the model to dynamically filter the columns.

entries.name: Comparison of QwQ and combinations
entries.description: `qwq-chart.js` emphasizes the solo model in green, the architect+editor in blue, breaks the captions into two lines when `+` and synchronizes the table with the search.

entries.name: List of blog articles
entries.description: `blog/index.html` displays all posts (except draft), uses excerpt if possible, shows highlight_image and date, forming a blog feed.

entries.name: The first GPT code benchmarks
entries.description: The post runs the Exercism benchmark: compares whole/diff and function-calling formats, finds that markdown blocks give better results, and OpenAI functions worsen code quality and format compliance.

entries.name: Speed tests GPT-4 Turbo
entries.description: The report measures the response time of 1106 models: it records acceleration of GPT-3.5 by 6-11 times, GPT-4 Turbo by 2-2.5 times and compares with March 3.5.

entries.name: Aider writes his own code
entries.description: The article documents that aider created 7% of the current rows (and notes the updated metric of 70%), citing a table `git blame` by files and scripts.

entries.name: Stability Claude Sonnet
entries.description: The publication analyzes Sonnet's historical runs on Exercism with a pass rate chart, refutes nerf rumors and highlights the 2% spread.

entries.name: QwQ as an architect
entries.description: The post explains that QwQ 32B Preview does not cope well with edit formats solo, but paired with Qwen 2.5 Coder it reaches 74% and requires an architect/workflow editor.

entries.name: New polyglot leaderboard
entries.description: The material presents a benchmark of 225 complex tasks (C++, Go, Java, JS, Python, Rust), notes o1-high leadership and explains the criteria for selecting exercises.

entries.name: Alternatives to DeepSeek V3
entries.description: The post describes the instability of the DeepSeek API, compares OpenRouter, Fireworks, Hyperbolic and Ollama, showing configs `.aider.model.settings.yml` for each provider.

entries.name: Gemini cost fix
entries.description: The article admits that the price of $6.32 for Gemini 2.5 Pro Preview was erroneous due to the lack of reasoning tokens in litellm, records the commits of fixes and the timeline.

entries.name: Qwen3 results
entries.description: The post aggregates Qwen3 runs on the polyglot benchmark for different providers/formats, provides an interactive table with filtering and a description of the settings used.

entries.name: Fallback launch when aider command is missing
entries.description: The page explains that the shell's failure to find the aider binary is most often due to PATH restrictions (especially on Windows), and recommends running `python -m aider` as a guaranteed workaround until re-installation is done via aider-install, uv or pipx.

entries.name: Tips for troubleshooting edit application errors
entries.description: The guide describes how "Failed to apply edit" failures occur due to incorrect LLM response formats, and advises limiting the number of files in the context, clearing history, switching to stronger models or whole/architect mode to improve model discipline.

entries.name: Resolving dependency conflicts and ImportError
entries.description: The material examines package version conflicts between the project and aider, warns about the risks of packages from managers like Homebrew/AUR, and strongly recommends separate installation via aider-install, uv or pipx in order to preserve the pinned dependency versions.

entries.name: Selecting a model using available API keys
entries.description: The document describes how aider automatically selects a model based on available keys, offers fast onboarding via OpenRouter if they are missing, and provides examples of launching with explicit parameters `--model` And `--api-key` for different providers.

entries.name: /help command with RAG for all documentation
entries.description: The page demonstrates that `/help <question>` searches the entire aider documentation, mixes the found texts into the context and generates a response taking into account the current conversation, which turns the command into a built-in RAG assistant.

entries.name: Reports on exceeding token limits and ways to bypass them
entries.description: The guide explains that aider only relays provider errors about context window overflow or output limit, and advises reducing the input (\/drop, /clear, splitting tasks) or increasing the output due to stronger models and the infinite output mode.

entries.name: Parsing warnings about models and environment variables
entries.description: A quick cheat sheet lists common aider warnings about unknown context size, unrecognized models, and missing environment variables and links to advanced model settings to resolve the messages.

entries.name: Need more help template
entries.description: `help.md` directs users to GitHub issues and Discord, lists data that is worth attaching, and inserts an example of aider announcement starting lines.

entries.name: Aider browser interface with --browser flag
entries.description: The documentation describes an experimental web UI that runs via `aider --browser`, connects to a local git repo and supports GPT-4o, Sonnet 3.7 and DeepSeek, keeping automatic commits.

entries.name: Prompt caching for savings and speed
entries.description: The article explains how `--cache-prompts` allows you to cache system prompts, read-only files and repo-maps when working with Anthropic and DeepSeek, and keepalive pings `--cache-keepalive-pings` prevent cache expiration.

entries.name: Complete reference to slash commands
entries.description: The section contains a generated table of all chat commands (\/add, /model, /run, /voice, etc.), tips for re-entering and a block about prompt-toolkit hotkeys, which makes the page the main reference for session management.

entries.name: Coding conventions via read-only files
entries.description: The material suggests storing development rules in markdown and connecting them via `/read` or `.aider.conf.yml`, showing an example where LLM starts using httpx and types after loading CONVENTIONS.md.

entries.name: Connection with web chats via copy/paste mode
entries.description: Page describes `/copy-context`, `/paste` and mode `--copy-paste`, which helps to combine aider with web interfaces of models, saving manual steps so as not to violate the terms of use of services.

entries.name: Working with images and web pages in chat
entries.description: The document lists ways to add images via `/add`, `/paste` or command line arguments and shows how `/web <url>` or `aider.scrape` upload documentation to chat.

entries.name: Auto-linting and autotests after each edit
entries.description: The guide describes the operation of built-in linters, settings `--lint-cmd`/`--test-cmd`, mode `--auto-test` and scripts with compiled languages, as well as the command `/run` for manual start.

entries.name: Code, ask, architect and help modes
entries.description: The page explains switching via `/chat-mode`, recommends workflow ask->code, details the architect mode with a dedicated editor model and example scripts.

entries.name: Using aider for configs and documentation
entries.description: The material shows how aider edits shell and ssh configs, Dockerfile, .gitconfig, markdown and XML, providing real session transcripts as the basis for non-technical scripts.

entries.name: Notifications when responses are ready
entries.description: Section describes the flag `--notifications`, platform commands (terminal-notifier, notify-send, PowerShell) and the ability to set `--notifications-command`, including integration via Apprise.

entries.name: Practical Tips for Pair Programming
entries.description: The summary reminds you to add only the necessary files, split goals, alternate ask and code, use `/run`, `/test`, `/clear` and change patterns while staying in the productive cycle.

entries.name: A selection of training videos from the community
entries.description: The page aggregates the latest videos about architect/editor mode, Replit, full-stack and game examples, which is useful for onboarding new users.

entries.name: Voice input using the /voice command
entries.description: The material describes how `/voice` starts the recording, transcribes the instructions into the chat and refers to enabling the option in the installation, demonstrating a dialog example.

entries.name: --watch-files mode and AI comments
entries.description: The guide shows how aider catches one-line comments with `AI!` or `AI?`, reacts to them with editing or replies and how to combine this mode with terminal chat.

entries.name: Publishing shared chats
entries.description: Page `share/index.md` renders transcripts from parameter `mdurl`, filters invalid URLs, converts gists to raw form and cleans Markdown via DOMPurify.

entries.name: Hint on `/help`
entries.description: Short include `help-tip.md` adds callout: how to use `/help <question>` and a link to the support page.

entries.name: Techniques for sending multi-line messages
entries.description: `multi-line.md` gives a list of methods: curly braces, tags `{python ...}`, Meta-Enter, `/paste`, `/editor` And `/multiline-mode`, and also explains why Shift+Enter is not available.

entries.name: Methods for setting API keys
entries.description: The document summarizes all key storage options: special flags for OpenAI/Anthropic, environment variables, `.env` and section `api-key` V `.aider.conf.yml`, including syntax `--api-key provider=...`.

entries.name: Setting up reasoning models
entries.description: Page covers `--reasoning-effort`, `--thinking-tokens`, check `accepts_settings` and the ability to disable validation, and also explains the use `reasoning_tag` for providers like DeepSeek R1.

entries.name: Structure and priorities of .aider.conf.yml
entries.description: The material lists the search order for configs (home/git root/current folder), shows the syntax of the lists, includes a full example file and a link to the generated sample.

entries.name: Using .env for aider settings
entries.description: The article describes the connection procedure `.env`, compatible with `--env-file` and contains a sample file with many AIDER_* parameters for bulk configuration.

entries.name: Advanced model settings
entries.description: This section explains how to register unknown models via `.aider.model.metadata.json` And `.aider.model.settings.yml`, set `extra_params` and global `aider/extra_params` For `litellm.completion`.

entries.name: Selecting an editor for the /editor command
entries.description: The article describes the flag `--editor`, AIDER_EDITOR/VISUAL/EDITOR variable priority, system defaults, and example commands with `--wait` for popular editors.

entries.name: Complete help on CLI options
entries.description: The generated section outputs `aider --help` with all the flags, grouping them by topic and connecting a reusable block about keys from `keys.md`.

entries.name: Model aliases and priorities
entries.description: Page describes `--alias`, configuration in `.aider.conf.yml`, built-in abbreviations (sonnet, gemini, etc.) and priority of overrides between CLI, config and defaults.

entries.name: Jekyll _config.yml wires analytics, nav, and callouts
entries.description: `website/_config.yml` includes theme `just-the-docs`, explicit links in `aux_links`/`nav_external_links`, disables the cookie banner via `analytics.enabled: false` and configures `callouts` colors. This file defines plugins, exceptions and CSS compression, so edits to it immediately change the global configuration of aider.chat.

entries.name: Sample .aider.conf.yml documents every CLI option
entries.description: `website/assets/sample.aider.conf.yml` publishes a commented template `.aider.conf.yml`: it lists all the keys (`model`, `architect`, `auto-accept-architect`, `reasoning-effort`, `load`, `voice-*` etc.) with an explanatory comment. This file is used in the documentation as a reference for what options ConfigArgParse supports.

entries.name: Minimal layout redirect
entries.description: Sample `_layouts/redirect.html` exposes `<meta http-equiv='refresh'>`, canonical link and fallback link for pages that should be redirected instantly.

entries.name: Custom `<head>` site
entries.description: `head_custom.html` adds OG images, loading a custom GlassTTY font, setting a sidebar gradient and initializing the consent/PostHog cookie when analytics is enabled.

entries.name: Navigation by API keys
entries.description: `keys.md` inserts a tip with a link to `/docs/config/api-keys.html`to redirect users from different configuration pages.

entries.name: Installation in Replit via pipx
entries.description: A short note recommends installing pipx inside Replit, running `pipx run aider-chat` and warns about an error `libstdc++.so.6`, if you try to call binary `aider` directly.

entries.name: Launch on GitHub Codespaces
entries.description: The material advises using the built-in Codespaces terminal, repeating the basic installation steps and contains a video of the process.

entries.name: Optional steps after installation
entries.description: The section lists additional steps: installing git, getting API keys, setting up Playwright for `/web`, PortAudio connection for `/voice` and IDE plugins via `--watch-files`.

entries.name: Docker images aider core and full
entries.description: The article compares images `paulgauthier/aider` And `aider-full`, leads commands `docker run` with project mapping, reminds you to configure git user/email and warns about restrictions `/run` and "/voice" inside the container.

entries.name: Reusable install block
entries.description: `install.md` reduces installation of aider to two commands `python -m pip install aider-install` And `aider-install`so that pages can include the same bootstrap.

entries.name: Hint about `python -m aider`
entries.description: `python-m-aider.md` suggests running `python -m aider`, If `aider` is not in PATH, and links to the troubleshooting page.

entries.name: Tips for pipx in Replit
entries.description: `replit-pipx.md` describes commands `pip install pipx` And `pipx run aider-chat`, warning about crash `libstdc++.so.6` when trying to call the binary directly.

entries.name: Connecting OpenAI models
entries.description: The page describes setting the variable `OPENAI_API_KEY`, startup examples `o3-mini`, `o1-mini`, `gpt-4o` and notes the limitations of reasoning models, which sometimes require separate parameter settings.

entries.name: Using OpenRouter with custom routing
entries.description: Section explains setup `OPENROUTER_API_KEY`, lists commands `aider --model openrouter/...`, warns about privacy settings and shows how to `.aider.model.settings.yml` limit the list of providers.

entries.name: Anthropic Connection and Limitations
entries.description: The article describes the use `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`, how Sonnet works by default, warnings about limits and example settings `.aider.model.settings.yml` to enable thinking tokens.

entries.name: DeepSeek API and Chat V3 model
entries.description: The short section recommends asking `DEEPSEEK_API_KEY` and shows an example of running `aider --model deepseek/deepseek-chat`, highlighting the model's performance in the benchmark.

entries.name: Connecting free Groq models
entries.description: The guide notes free access, necessity `GROQ_API_KEY` and team `aider --model groq/llama3-70b-8192`, as well as a hint `--list-models groq/`.

entries.name: Working with Gemini 2.5 via aider
entries.description: The article describes the setup `GEMINI_API_KEY`, abbreviations `--model gemini` And `gemini-exp`, as well as the need to install the package `google-generativeai` through the manager you are using.

entries.name: Amazon Bedrock Integration
entries.description: The material lists the steps: selecting modelId/Inference Profile, setting up AWS creds via CLI or variables, launching `aider --model bedrock/...` and a hint about installing boto3.

entries.name: Local models via Ollama
entries.description: The document covers installation `OLLAMA_API_BASE`, recommendation to use the prefix `ollama_chat/`, the need to increase `num_ctx` and show the configuration via `.aider.model.settings.yml`.

entries.name: Azure OpenAI deployments
entries.description: The article describes the variables `AZURE_API_KEY`, `AZURE_API_BASE`, `AZURE_API_VERSION`, launch `aider --model azure/<deployment>` and clarifies that the list of models reflects those supported by aider, and not a specific account.

entries.name: Cohere setup walkthrough
entries.description: The page explains that Cohere provides free access to Command-R+, shows the same installation `COHERE_API_KEY` for macOS/Windows and launch examples `aider --model command-r-plus-08-2024` or `--list-models cohere_chat/` after basic installation of aider.

entries.name: GitHub Copilot via OpenAI endpoint
entries.description: The instructions translate Copilot to an OpenAI-compatible URL `https://api.githubcopilot.com`, shows how to extract `oauth_token` from `apps.json`, configure `OPENAI_API_BASE/KEY`, list available models via curl and commit example `.aider.conf.yml` for a stable connection.

entries.name: LM Studio local models
entries.description: The guide emphasizes the obligatory dummy `LM_STUDIO_API_KEY`, configures the base URL `http://localhost:1234/v1` and demonstrates the launch `aider --model lm_studio/<model>` with a reminder to check warnings about unknown models.

entries.name: Connecting OpenAI-compatible APIs
entries.description: The page describes the generic setup `OPENAI_API_BASE`/`OPENAI_API_KEY`, shows how to prefix models `openai/<model-name>` and refers to a warning block for unfamiliar providers.

entries.name: Directory of other providers
entries.description: The material explains that aider relies on LiteLLM, advises using `aider --list-models <pattern>` for auto-substitution of names and provides a complete list of environment variables `*_API_KEY`, which LiteLLM recognizes.

entries.name: Vertex AI authorization and models
entries.description: The guide requires installing gcloud, relies on `GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS`, sets `VERTEXAI_PROJECT`/`VERTEXAI_LOCATION` V `.env` and shows startup examples `aider --model vertex_ai/claude-3-5-sonnet@20240620` or configuration via `.aider.conf.yml`.

entries.name: Model Warnings Page
entries.description: Section aggregates include `model-warnings.md`, so that the documentation contains messages about unknown costs, Did you mean hints, and checks for missing environment variables.

entries.name: xAI Grok connection
entries.description: The page describes obtaining a key on console.x.ai, setting up `XAI_API_KEY`, demonstrates commands for `grok-3`/`grok-3-mini` and notes support `--reasoning-effort` for Grok 3 Mini with a link to the relevant documentation.

entries.name: Reusable warning block
entries.description: `model-warnings.md` describes Unknown context window, Did you mean, and missing variables scenarios, including advice to ignore some warnings and restarting the Windows terminal for others.

entries.name: Interactive polyglot leaderboard
entries.description: The main page of the leaderboards shows an interactive table of the polyglot benchmark with filters, pop-up details and visualization of cost and percentage of successful solutions.

entries.name: Classic code-editing benchmark
entries.description: The page records a historical leaderboard of 133 Exercism problems, explains metrics for solution percentage and diff format compliance, and contains a generated graph.

entries.name: Leaderboard for refactoring large methods
entries.description: The section describes a set of 89 large methods aimed at checking the "lazyness" of models, provides a table of results and a graph for models with large contexts.

entries.name: Explanations of metrics and prices
entries.description: The page is suitable as a methodological supplement: it describes accuracy, format correctness, costing policy and general notes on edit formats.

entries.name: Accuracy chart by model release date
entries.description: The mini-page contains a link to an SVG graph of models over time, allowing you to compare the evolution of code editing quality by release date.

entries.name: Architect leaderboard YAML enumerates paired-model runs
entries.description: `projects/Aider/aider/website/_data/architect.yml` lists each run of the architect benchmark along with `model`, `editor_model`/`editor_edit_format`, percent `pass_rate_1`/`pass_rate_2`, time for the task and `total_cost`. These fields are picked up by site pages to compare which o1/gpt/claude pairs give the best result and which `aider --model` startup data is removed.

entries.name: Blame dataset tracks aider vs human commits per release
entries.description: `website/_data/blame.yml` stores a time series between tags `start_tag`/`end_tag`: percentage of rows `aider_percentage`, total number of rows and breakdown `file_counts` by authors. The blame graphs on the site read this YAML to show the percentage of auto-generated changes by file and release.

entries.name: Code-in-JSON benchmark data feeds JSON/Markdown comparisons
entries.description: `website/_data/code-in-json.yml` captures JSON-mode runs: `edit_format`, `percent_cases_well_formed`, number of errors, `seconds_per_case` And `total_cost`. These entries allow the Code-in-JSON page to compare Markdown and pure JSON output for the same Exercism tasks.

entries.name: DeepSeek downtime dataset records failure-heavy runs
entries.description: `website/_data/deepseek-down.yml` lists December and January DeepSeek/Fireworks runs with 225 tasks, recording `pass_num_1`, `num_malformed_responses`, timeouts and cost. This YAML is embedded under the DeepSeek down blog to show how much the answers were degraded and how many errors the model was producing.

entries.name: Edit leaderboard data lists diff vs whole runs
entries.description: `website/_data/edit_leaderboard.yml` keeps the history of the classic 133-problem set: for each entry it is indicated `edit_format`, days of issue, interest `pass_rate_*`, syntax warnings and `command`to replay the run. The edit leaderboard page sorts this YAML to compare diff and whole modes.

entries.name: o1 polyglot YAML compares architect/editor pairings
entries.description: `website/_data/o1_polyglot_leaderboard.yml` stores 225 case runs for o1-preview, gpt-4o and sonnet: directory identifiers, `pass_num_1/2`, number `user_asks`, timeouts and cost. These values feed into a polyglot leaderboard, where you can see how much architectural pairings improve results.

entries.name: o1 results dataset captures early architect experiments
entries.description: `website/_data/o1_results.yml` collects summer launches of gpt-4o-mini and claude-3.5-sonnet indicating `edit_format`, precision, numbers `error_outputs` and costs. The material is used on the site to show how architecture and diff modes affect the o1 series.

entries.name: Polyglot leaderboard data tracks 225 multilingual cases
entries.description: `website/_data/polyglot_leaderboard.yml` aggregates 225-case measurements for Gemini, gpt-4o-mini and other models: stores `total_tests`, `pass_rate_*`, number of errors and cost. This data feeds the main polyglot leaderboard table on aider.chat.

entries.name: Quant leaderboard dataset compares HF and Ollama assemblies
entries.description: `website/_data/quant.yml` captures the results of quantized Qwen2.5 via GLHF and Ollama: stores `model`, boundary `pass_rate_*`, number `num_malformed_responses` and the commands used. The quant leaderboard page reads these posts to show the tradeoffs between fps16 and bf16 deliveries.

entries.name: Qwen3 leaderboard data records long-running thinking trials
entries.description: `website/_data/qwen3_leaderboard.yml` describes 225 tasks for Qwen3 32B/235B: fields `prompt_tokens`, `completion_tokens`, `seconds_per_case`, quantity `error_outputs` And `exhausted_context_windows`. These metrics are used on the site to explain why Qwen3's thinking modes take hours and what their success rate is.

entries.name: QwQ architect data compares Haiku and DeepSeek editors
entries.description: `website/_data/qwq.yml` records architect runs of QwQ with Haiku and DeepSeek editor models: stores `editor_model`, `editor_edit_format`, numbers `user_asks`, timings and cost. These posts feed the QwQ blog, showing the benefits of the editor's choices.

entries.name: R1 architect dataset logs Sonnet editor altitude
entries.description: `website/_data/r1_architect.yml` contains both pure R1 diff and R1+Sonnet architect runs: fields `pass_num_1/2`, `user_asks`, `total_cost` and start command. This data forms the basis of the blog about the R1 architecture, showing the increase in quality and price due to the Sonnet editor.

entries.name: Refactor leaderboard data highlights lazy comments
entries.description: `website/_data/refactor_leaderboard.yml` stores 89-task refactor runs: share visible `lazy_comments`, `percent_cases_well_formed`, number of syntax and indentation errors. The refactor leaderboard page reads this YAML to show how the models handle a large method and how many garbage responses they generate.

entries.name: Claude 3.5 Sonnet fine-tune runs feed leaderboard diffs
entries.description: `website/_data/sonnet-fine.yml` lists openrouter/claude-3.5-sonnet launches in diff and udiff formats: stores `pass_rate_*`, `error_outputs`, `thinking`- settings and precise `command`. These entries allow the site to show how much udiff improves accuracy compared to the classic Sonnet diff.

entries.name: How to send benchmark results
entries.description: The page directs volunteers: a link to the README of the benchmark, a PR requirement in `_data/` and indicates that aider accepts Exercism benchmark results via GitHub.

entries.name: JS visualization of a polyglot leaderboard
entries.description: `leaderboard.js` builds a mixed bar/dot plot according to `allData`, highlights selected rows, switches whole vs diff patterns and supports highlighting models via query string.

entries.name: Universal include graphics
entries.description: `leaderboard_graph.html` accepts data through include parameters and synchronizes with the table, allowing you to filter models with a click and color code edit formats.

entries.name: Interactive table Qwen3
entries.description: `leaderboard_table.js` implements view/select/detail modes, inserts cost progress bars, supports filtering and synchronizes selection with charts.

entries.name: Development Screen Recording Directory
entries.description: The main post page lists videos of the author using aider to refine aider, with a brief description of each scenario.

entries.name: Video about saving read-only files with /drop
entries.description: The recording shows how aider modifies the command `/drop`, adds tests and manually checks the behavior, commenting each step.

entries.name: Connection script tree-sitter-language-pack
entries.description: The video demonstrates how aider writes scripts to load tags files, updates Grep-AST, creates fixtures and diagnoses problems using an Arduino/TSX example.

entries.name: Auto-accept architect audio metadata provides minute markers
entries.description: `website/assets/audio/auto-accept-architect/metadata.json` stores a frame-by-frame transcript of the recording about the automatic acceptance of architect changes: keys `MM-SS` -> comment text. These captions allow the recording page to provide an accessible audio player with precise hints about where flags are added to the video.

entries.name: Don't drop read files transcript highlights CLI walkthrough
entries.description: `website/assets/audio/dont-drop-original-read-files/metadata.json` contains discussion timeline `/drop` protection: you can see the moments when the command and HISTORY update are demonstrated. These captions allow users to follow a recording without listening to all the audio.

entries.name: Model accepts settings metadata timestamps reasoning demo
entries.description: `website/assets/audio/model-accepts-settings/metadata.json` records how the author shows the check `accepts_settings` and manual tests. The JSON shows at what minute the flag is turned on and documents the behavior, making it easier to quickly navigate through the entry.

entries.name: Tree-sitter language pack recording ships searchable transcript
entries.description: `website/assets/audio/tree-sitter-language-pack/metadata.json` gives a transcript of a long session for loading tree-sitter tags: lines with minutes describe the loading of Grep-AST, fixtures and tests. This makes it easier to find the step you need without going through the entire recording.

entries.name: Video tutorial on --auto-accept-architect
entries.description: The screen recording demonstrates adding the auto-accept architect's edits flag, manual testing, and updating HISTORY with timecodes for each stage.

entries.name: Video about warnings reasoning settings
entries.description: The recording shows the implementation of checking supported reasoning settings, updating the YAML model database, manual tests and finalizing the documentation with step-by-step comments.

entries.name: JS management Asciinema
entries.description: `recording.js` builds AsciinemaPlayer with markers from comments, supports voice acting and toast, adapts fullscreen and detects devices without a hardware keyboard.

entries.name: HTML framework of the recording player
entries.description: `recording.md` connects styles, scripts and builds a terminal mockup with key hints so that reuse on all post pages is uniform.
